Interface IPlayerManager

public interface IPlayerManager
Manager for persistent player data in the ProudCore system.

IPlayerManager is responsible for the full lifecycle of IPlayerData records: loading them from the database, keeping them in a fast in-memory cache while a player is online, and flushing them back to storage on logout or server shutdown.

Caching behaviour

Online players always have their data pre-loaded in memory — reads are therefore instantaneous and produce no I/O. For offline players, the first call to getPlayer(UUID) may trigger a synchronous database read if the record is not cached; use isLoaded(UUID) to check beforehand if latency is a concern.

Guaranteed non-null returns

getPlayer(UUID) never returns null. If no record exists for the given UUID, a default one is created and cached on the spot. This simplifies calling code because null-checks are unnecessary.

Usage example

IPlayerManager players = ProudCoreAPI.get().getPlayerManager();

// Read player power — always safe, never null
IPlayerData data = players.getPlayer(playerUuid);
System.out.printf("Power: %.1f / %.1f%n", data.getPower(), data.getMaxPower());

// Efficient bulk operation — only iterate already-loaded data
for (Player online : Bukkit.getOnlinePlayers()) {
    UUID uuid = online.getUniqueId();
    if (players.isLoaded(uuid)) {
        players.getPlayer(uuid).addPower(1.0); // passive regen tick
    }
}
Since:
1.0

  • Method Details

    • getPlayer

      IPlayerData getPlayer(UUID uuid)
      Returns the IPlayerData record for the given player, loading it from the database if necessary.

      This method guarantees a non-null return value: if no existing record is found for the UUID, a fresh default record is created, cached, and returned. There is therefore no need to null-check the result.

      Performance note: For online players, data is served directly from the in-memory cache with no I/O overhead. For offline players whose data is not cached, a synchronous database read occurs on the first call. If you need to avoid that latency, guard the call with isLoaded(UUID).

      Parameters:
      uuid - the UUID of the player whose data is requested; must not be null
      Returns:
      the non-null IPlayerData for that player

    • isLoaded

      boolean isLoaded(UUID uuid)
      Returns true if the given player's data is currently held in the in-memory cache.

      All online players are guaranteed to have their data cached. Offline players may or may not be cached depending on whether their data was loaded for a recent operation and has not yet been evicted.

      This method is particularly useful before performing bulk operations over a large player set: iterating only over cached players avoids triggering unintended database reads for every offline UUID.

      if (!playerManager.isLoaded(uuid)) {
    // Skip — loading this offline player's data just for a stat update
    // is not worth the I/O cost.
    return;
}
playerManager.getPlayer(uuid).addPower(bonus);
      Parameters:
      uuid - the UUID of the player to check; must not be null
      Returns:
      true if the player's data is in the cache, false if it would require a database load

    • saveAll

      void saveAll()
      Forces an immediate flush of all cached player data to persistent storage.

      Under normal operation, ProudCore persists data automatically at configurable intervals and whenever a player disconnects. Call this method explicitly only in situations where data integrity is critical and cannot wait for the next scheduled save — for example:

      • Just before a controlled server shutdown initiated by a plugin.
      • After a bulk administrative operation that modified many records.
      • As a safety net before executing a risky or irreversible game action.

      Threading note: Depending on the implementation, this call may block until all I/O completes. Avoid invoking it on the main server thread in latency-sensitive code paths.
